predicate.note: Frames file for 'pass' based on survey of initial sentences of big corpus and comparison with 'fail', 'give', 'send', and reference to verbnet classes give-13.1, send-11.1, and throw-17.1. There are probably a million senses and phrasals I've missed; the syntax tends to be pretty straightforward, so if you encounter them while tagging just go ahead and add them.

example.name: passive
example.text: The Senate-House conference committee is used when a bill is passed *trace* by the House and Senate in different forms.

example.name: distinguishing arg1 from arg2
example.text: John passed the bill into law.

example.name: transitive
example.text: A couple of my law clerks were going *trace* to pass me in three or four years.

example.name: time passes
example.text: Hardly a day passes without news photos of the police dragging limp protestors from some building.
example.arg: without news photos of the police dragging limp protestors from some building

example.name: no object
example.text: Faced with a losing poker hand, John passed.
example.arg: Faced with a losing poker hand

example.name: NP object
example.text: Warner has passed *trace*, or chosen not to produce, at least 76.

example.name: PP object
example.text: John passed on the opportunity to go spelunking.

roleset.name: give

example.name: idiomatic meaning, compositional syntax
example.text: He is just passing the buck to young people.

roleset.note: Similarly "pass_along", which is often misparsed in Treebank.

example.name: pass for
example.text: ...the claptrap that *trace* passes for consensus in various international institutions.

roleset.name: pass a class, pass a test

example.name: success!
example.text: The number of balloonists who *trace* have passed a Federal Aviation Authority lighter-than-air test has doubled in the last year.
example.arg: a Federal Aviation Authority lighter-than-air test

roleset.note: One presumes the test itself is not lighter than air.

example.name: one of many
example.text: Many are far enough from residential areas *trace* to pass public muster.

example.name: give
example.text: Insurers typically pass on a small percentage of the risks they underwrite (to their customers).
example.arg: a small percentage of the risks they underwrite

example.name: passive
example.text: The test booklets were passed *trace* out 48 hours ahead of time.

example.name: sexist, sorry
example.text: Mary passes out at the sight of blood.

example.name: transitive active
example.text: ...a small French merchant bank that Deutsche Bank had looked at and passed *trace* over.

example.name: transitive
example.text: Gorbachev is unlikely *trace* to pass up the opportunity to press once again for negotiated cuts in the navies of both nations.
example.arg: the opportunity to press once again for negotiated cuts in the navies of both nations

example.name: passive
example.text: Both the costs and the savings could be passed on to shippers on the TransCanada pipeline.
example.arg: Both the costs and the savings

example.name: so sorry
example.text: John's cat passed on last week.
